content.title: Solution for Problem 11.23
content.content: Since we have a Diophantine equation (meaning we are looking only for integer solutions), we look for a way to factor the left side. Unfortunately, we can't factor $mn + m + n$, but we can factor an $m$ from the first two terms:
content.notes: While we can't factor the left side as is, we could factor it if the second $n$ were an $n + 1$. This guides us to add 1 to both sides. We use the two factorizations of 77 to look for solutions. The case $(m + 1)(n + 1) = 77 \cdot 1$ gives $(m, n) = (76, 0)$ and $(m, n) = (0, 76)$ as solutions, but $m$ and $n$ must be positive, so we discard these. The case $(m + 1)(n + 1) = 11 \cdot 7$ gives $(m, n) = (10, 6)$ and $(m, n) = (6, 10)$ as solutions.

content.content: Find all pairs of integers $b$ and $c$ that satisfy the equation $bc - 7b + 3c = 70$.

content.title: Solution for Problem 11.24
content.content: Once again we'd like to factor the left side, but how? Since we have the product $bc$ and linear terms $-7b$ and $+3c$, we guess the factorization will be of the form $(b + \_)(c + \_)$.
content.notes: The expansion of this product clearly has a $bc$ term, as desired. It must also have $+3c$ term, so the blank in $(b + \_)$ must be 3, so it will combine with the $c$ in $(c + \_)$ to give $3c$. Similarly, we need a $-7b$ term, so the blank in $(c + \_)$ must be $-7$. Expanding this product gives $(b + 3)(c - 7) = bc - 7b + 3c - 21$, so we must add 21 from both sides of our equation. These factorizations of 49 give us six cases to consider for solutions.

content.title: Solution for Problem 11.25
content.content: We could try trial and error, but how would we know if we've found all the solutions? Instead, we look for an organized approach. First, we deal with the variables in the denominators. We don't like fractions, so we multiply both sides of the equation by $mn$ to get rid of them.
content.notes: We have the product of two variables, $mn$, and linear terms with those variables, $4n$ and $2m$. This gets us thinking about Simon's Favorite Factoring Trick. We move all the terms to one side, giving $mn - 2m - 4n = 0$. We'd like to factor the left side as $(m + \_)(n + \_)$. Because we need a $-4n$ term and a $-2m$ term, the factorization we seek is $(m - 4)(n - 2)$. Expanding this product gives $(m - 4)(n - 2) = mn - 2m - 4n + 8$, so we must add 8 to both sides of our equation $mn - 2m - 4n = 0$ in order to be able to factor the left side. We don't have to consider $(-8) \cdot (-1)$ or $(-4) \cdot (-2)$ because we are asked for positive integer solutions, and these cases produce nonpositive integers for $m$ and/or $n$ in each case. Each case gives a valid solution, so there are 4 ordered pairs that satisfy the original equation.

content.title: Algebraic Equation
content.definition: An algebraic equation is an equation which involves at least one variable.

content.title: LINEAR EQUATIONS
content.definition: A linear equation contains at least a variable which can only be raised to the power 1.

content.title: Sides of an Equation
content: The left hand side (LHS) of an equation is on the left of the $=$ sign.
The right hand side (RHS) of an equation is on the right of the $=$ sign.

content.title: Solution of a Linear Equation
content.definition: The solution of a linear equation is the value of the variable which makes the equation true. In other words, it makes the left hand side (LHS) equal to the right hand side (RHS).

content.title: Algebraic Solution to Linear Equations
content.content: The following steps should be followed to solve linear equations:
steps: Step 1: Decide how the expression containing the unknown has been 'built up'.
Step 2: Perform inverse operations on both sides of the equation to 'undo' how the equation is 'built up'. In this way we isolate the unknown.
Step 3: Check your solution by substitution.
